item.title: New Generation of Combat Vets, Eyeing House, Strike From the Right
item.description: A class of political newcomers with remarkable military records are challenging old ideas about interventionism — and the assumption that electing veterans is a way to bring back bipartisanship.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Nathan Howard/Getty Images
item.media:description: Joe Kent prays with supporters at a campaign event in Kent, Wash.

item.title: Far-Right Republicans Face Tough Races in Swing Districts, Testing McCarthy
item.description: The top House Republican spent freely to try to block extreme candidates who could imperil the party’s chances of winning the majority or challenge his path to the speakership. Some won anyway.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some extremist candidates have prevailed despite the efforts of Representative Kevin McCarthy of California, who tried to help defeat them in Republican primaries.

item.title: Putin Moves to Cement Annexations in Ukraine
item.description: Moscow is pressuring nuclear engineers to sign contracts with a Russian agency while pushing Ukrainians fleeing Kherson to go to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man walking in front of his home, which was struck overnight by a Russian missile in a town 30 miles south of Zaporizhzhia on Saturday.

item.title: Raphael Warnock and Herschel Walker Debate in Georgia
item.description: Herschel Walker, needing to recover from weeks of negative headlines, went on the offensive against Senator Raphael Warnock in what is likely to be the only debate of their crucial Senate race.
item.dc:creator: Maya King and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times; Nicole Buchanan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Herschel Walker and Senator Raphael Warnock

item.title: What Was That Badge Herschel Walker Flashed in His Debate?
item.description: The Republican Senate candidate in Georgia was scolded by a debate moderator and derided online after flashing an honorary badge during an exchange with Senator Raphael Warnock, the Democratic incumbent.
item.dc:creator: Maya King and Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: NewsNation via Reuters

item.title: The Rent Revolution Is Coming
item.description: For the 44 million households who rent a home or apartment in the U.S., inflation keeps pushing costs higher and higher. Anger is rising too. It could be a breaking point.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty
item.media:credit: Barrett Emke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tiana Caldwell, a co-founder and Board President of KC Tenants, outside the East Patrol Division Station in Kansas City after being arrested during the group's disruption of a city council vote on a new set of housing ordinances.

item.title: Suspect in Stockton, Calif., Series of Killings Is Arrested, Police Say
item.description: The 43-year-old man was arrested early on Saturday while he was “out hunting” for another victim, said the police chief, who added, “We are sure we stopped another killing.”
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina

item.title: How Volunteers Open Their Homes to Women Seeking Abortions
item.description: Home stays have roots in a pre-Roe America, where women frequently traveled long distances for abortions.
item.dc:creator: Ronda Kaysen
item.media:credit: Mustafa Hussain for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jill is part of a network of volunteers in Chicago who open their homes to people who travel from out of state to get abortions.

item.title: Can Black Literature Escape the Representation Trap?
item.description: A crop of recent novels strains against the expectations of a publishing industry attempting to embrace diversity.
item.dc:creator: Ismail Muhammad

item.title: When Sarcastic Fringeheads Open Their Mouths, Watch Out
item.description: Scientists found that the fish’s unusual broad-mouthed display is reserved only for fighting with other members of its species.
item.dc:creator: Jason P. Dinh

item.title: Herschel Walker, Butcher of Language
item.description: The Republican Senate candidate is devastatingly inarticulate.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times

item.title: A Phone Call With Angela Lansbury Changed Me
item.description: Many prefer to airbrush vulnerabilities away, but Angela Lansbury brought a combination of dignity and forthrightness to her life and work.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Healy
item.category: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (Play)
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times

item.title: Same-Sex Marriage Is a Religious Freedom
item.description: If the law allows same-sex couples to be treated differently from other couples, then our religious freedom to be married is not complete.
item.dc:creator: Steven Paulikas
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:credit: Bryan Thomas for The New York Times

item.title: Politicians Have Always Paid Lip Service to Families. This Year Was Just a New Low.
item.description: Herschel Walker, meet Teddy Roosevelt.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Photographs by Megan Varner and Bettmann, via Getty Images

item.title: What My Students Don’t Know About Their Own History
item.description: When Lat see themselves represented it leaves them empowered and curious to learn more.
item.dc:creator: Arlene Dávila
item.media:credit: Dominic Bodden

item.title: Donald Trump Has Told Americans Exactly Who He Is
item.description: Even without his testimony, the Jan. 6 committee has revealed what we need to know about the former president.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Wegman
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: The Contradictions of Climate Activism
item.description: The energy crisis exposes the cracks in a low-carbon vision.
item.dc:creator: Ross Douthat
item.media:credit: Henry Nicholls/Reuters
item.media:description: A Just Stop Oil protester in London last week.

item.title: The Jan. 6 Hearings Are Over. These 3 Things Must Happen Now.
item.description: The torch now passes to other actors who hold the power to achieve accountability for the attack on the Capitol.

item.title: How to Get Rid of Bad Breath
item.description: Food choices, oral hygiene habits and certain health conditions can play a role — but there are ways to keep dragon breath in check.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Pablo Delcan; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: The Enduring Appeal of Ronaldo, Soccer’s Original Phenomenon
item.description: The Brazilian striker’s lasting power lies not so much in a deep trove of highlight clips, but in what he showed was possible.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith

item.title: Talk of ‘Civil War’ Flares Online and More: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.

item.title: Did You Recently Buy a Home in New York City for Less Than $750,000?
item.description: If so, we want to hear from you.

item.title: Evin, Iran’s Notorious Prison, Erupts in Fire
item.description: Evin Prison, in Tehran, houses hundreds of dissidents and political prisoners. Witnesses described hearing gunshots and explosions as a blaze made its way through the facility on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Reuters

item.title: When Segregationists Offered One-Way Tickets to Black Southerners
item.description: The “reverse freedom rides” of 1962 were meant to provoke Northern politicians, and have drawn comparisons to the recent flights of migrants to Martha’s Vineyard.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Jim Bourdier/Associated Press

item.title: Black Holes May Hide a Mind-Bending Secret About Our Universe
item.description: Take gravity, add quantum mechanics, stir. What do you get? Just maybe, a holographic cosmos.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Leonardo Santamaria

item.title: Biden’s Ire Won’t Keep U.S. Executives From Big Saudi Summit
item.description: The president warned Saudi Arabia that it would face “consequences” over oil cuts. Many Americans still plan to attend its investor conference this month.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Tasneem Alsultan for The New York Times
item.media:description: Guests at Saudi Arabia’s annual global business conference in Riyadh in 2019.

item.title: 4 Ways to Boost Your Immune System Ahead of Cold and Flu Season
item.description: Here are four things immunologists and other health experts say you can do.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Cristina Spanò

item.title: Is Matcha Good for You?
item.description: The brightly colored powdered green tea has become popular among health-conscious consumers. Does it have any nutritional benefits?
item.dc:creator: Annie Sneed
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: 6 Ways to Level Up Your Daily Walk
item.description: Experts say Americans are taking more walks than before the pandemic. Here are some ways to turn your neighborhood stroll in to an exciting workout.
item.dc:creator: Emily Pennington
item.media:credit: Yana Paskova for The New York Times

item.title: Vuity Review: I Swapped My Reading Glasses for Magical Eyedrops
item.description: Vuity, taken daily, promises clear vision for up to 10 hours. But does it work?
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Egan
item.media:credit: Desmond Picotte for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vuity, eyedrops that can help people see up close without affecting their long-range vision, went on the market in December.

item.title: ‘Halloween Ends’ Review: It Probably Doesn’t
item.description: David Gordon Green wraps up his reboot trilogy for a horror franchise that never stays dead for long.
item.dc:creator: Jeannette Catsoulis
item.media:credit: Ryan Green/Universal Pictures
item.media:description: Still a scream: Jamie Lee Curtis as Laurie Strode in “Halloween Ends.”

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
